article:
{{Infobox saint |name=Saint Bede the Venerable |birth_date=ca. 673 |death_date=26 May 735 |feast_day=25 May (Western Churches)
 27 May (Orthodox Church and General Roman Calendar, between
1899–1969) |venerated_in=Roman Catholic Church, Eastern Orthodox Church,
Anglican Communion, Lutheran Church |image=The Venerable Bede translates John
1902.jpg |caption=The Venerable Bede Translates John by J. D. Penrose (ca 1902)
|birth_place= not recorded, possibly Monkton.
|death_place=Jarrow, Northumbria |titles=Doctor of the
Church, Monk, Historian |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by=
|canonized_date=1899 recognised as Doctor of the Church |canonized_place=Rome
|canonized_by=Pope Leo XIII |patronage=English writers and historians; Jarrow
|major_shrine=Durham Cathedral. |suppressed_date= |issues= }} 'Bede' ( ; ;
672/673 â 26 May 735), also referred to as 'Saint Bede' or the 'Venerable Bede'
(), was an English monk at the Northumbrian monastery of Saint Peter at
Monkwearmouth and of its companion monastery, Saint Paul's, in modern Jarrow
(see Monkwearmouth-Jarrow), both in the Kingdom of Northumbria. He is well known
as an author and scholar, and his most famous work, [[Historia ecclesiastica
gentis Anglorum]] (The Ecclesiastical History of the English People) gained him
the title "The Father of English History".

In 1899, Bede was made a Doctor of the Church by Leo XIII, a position of
theological significance; he is the only native of Great Britain to achieve this
designation (Anselm of Canterbury, also a Doctor of the Church, was originally
from Italy). Bede was moreover a skilled linguist and translator, and his work
with the Latin and Greek writings of the early Church Fathers contributed
significantly to English Christianity, making the writings much more accessible
to his fellow Anglo-Saxons. Bede's monastery had access to a superb library
which included works by Eusebius and Orosius among many others.
categories: People from Sunderland, Tyne and Wear
headings: Works on historical and astronomical chronology
